In the 108th Congress, various bills related to voting rights and election integrity were introduced, including the Voter Protection Act of 2005 (S. 414), Count Every Vote Act of 2005 (S. 450), and S. 1986 which required voter-verification methods using accurate technology. S. 450 and S. 1986 had similar provisions on security review reports and consultation services by NIST, but differed in requirements for voting systems and additional provisions. S. 2313 also had voter-verification provisions similar to S. 450. The current bill, S. 450, includes provisions on communications devices, open-source software, security of state voter-registration lists, security standards for manufacturers, background checks, security consultation services by NIST, mandatory recounts, and repeal of the EAC's exemption from certain contracting requirements. It authorizes $150 million for verification requirements and omits deadlines for compliance with HAVA requirements and deployment of an interim paper system.
